review.title: A Collective, Probabilistic Approach to Schema Mapping: Appendix
review.abstract: In this appendix we provide additional supplementary material to "A Collective, Probabilistic Approach to Schema Mapping." We include an additional extended example, supplementary experiment details, and proof for the complexity result stated in the main paper.
histories: This is the appendix to the paper "A Collective, Probabilistic Approach to Schema Mapping" accepted to ICDE 2017
review.COMMENTS: This is the appendix to the paper "A Collective, Probabilistic Approach to Schema Mapping" accepted to ICDE 2017

metadata.title: A Collective, Probabilistic Approach to Schema Mapping: Appendix

sections.text: ar Xiv: 170 2.03 447v 1 [cs.D B] 11 Feb 2017A Collective, Probabilistic Approachto Schema Mapping: AppendixAngelika KimmigKU Leuvenangelika.kimmig @ cs.kuleuven.beAlex MemoryUniversity of Marylandmemory @ cs.umd.eduRene'e J. MillerUniversity of Torontomiller @ cs.toronto.eduLise GetoorUC Santa Cruzgetoor @ ucsc.eduIn this appendix we provide additional complementary material to "A Collective, Probabilistic Approach to Schema Mapping" [1]. We include an additional extended example, additional experimental details and evidence of the complexity given in the main article.

sections.heading: I. EXAMPLE OF SELECTION OVER ST TGDS
sections.text: We extend the running example from the main paper to illustrate objective equations. (9) of [1]. We use a reduced candidate set C ′ = {θ1, θ3} (Figure 1 (d) in [1]) and the data in Figure 1 (b) - (c) in [1], but ignore the leadership relationship. A universal solution Kθ1 by me contains the tuples of the task (BigData, Bob, Null1) and (ML, Alice, Null2) and the tuples of the task (Null3, IBM) and the org tuples (Null3, IBM).

sections.heading: II. SCENARIO GENERATION
sections.text: We use seven iBench primitives [2], [3]: CP copies a source relationship to the target and changes its name. ADD copies a source relationship and adds attributes; DL does the same but removes attributes instead; and ADL adds attributes to the same relationship and removes them. The number added or removed is controlled by range parameters we set (2,4). ME copies two relationships after we have connected them to form a target relationship. VP copies a source relationship to form two linked target relationships. VNM is the same as VP, but introduces an additional target relationship to form an N-to-M relationship between the other target relations (2,4). Modifying the metadata evidence by random correspondence.

sections.heading: III. MAPPING SELECTION IS NP-HARD
sections.text: We provide proof of the complexity of the results set out in section III-C of the main paper. (Theorem 1: The selection problem for complete st tgds, as defined in Eq. (4) Proof: We use a reduction of SET COVER, which is well known to be more complete, and is defined as follows: Given a finite number of U, a finite collection R = [Ri], which is a finite collection of R = [Ri], 1 ≤ i ≤ k} and a natural number n [R], which consists of most n sets Ri, we first consider the decision variant of the mapping selection, which is defined as follows: Given the schematic S, T, a data example (I, J), a set C of candidates full st tgds, and a natural number m, it is a selection M (M) with F (M).

metadata.abstractText: We extend the running example from the main paper to illustrate objective Eq. (9) of [1]. We use a reduced candidate set C = {θ1, θ3} (Figure 1(d) in [1]) and the data in Figure 1(b)-(c) in [1], but omit the leader relation. A universal solution Kθ1 of I contains the task tuples (BigData, Bob, Null1) and (ML, Alice, Null2), while a Kθ3 contains the task tuples (BigData, Bob, Null3) and (ML, Alice, Null4) and the org tuples (Null3, IBM) and (Null4, SAP).
